segment.source: Convert the rendering framework
segment.target: Convert the rendering framework

segment.source: Shows how to convert a simple rendering framework from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11, including how to port geometry buffers, how to compile and load HLSL shader programs, and how to implement the rendering chain in Direct3D 11.
segment.target: Shows how to convert a simple rendering framework from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11, including how to port geometry buffers, how to compile and load HLSL shader programs, and how to implement the rendering chain in Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Convert the rendering framework
segment.target: Convert the rendering framework

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.target: Part 1: Initialize Direct3D 11

segment.source: Shows how to convert a simple rendering framework from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11, including how to port geometry buffers, how to compile and load HLSL shader programs, and how to implement the rendering chain in Direct3D 11.
segment.target: Shows how to convert a simple rendering framework from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11, including how to port geometry buffers, how to compile and load HLSL shader programs, and how to implement the rendering chain in Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Part 2 of the Port a simple Direct3D 9 app to DirectX 11 and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) walkthrough.
segment.target: Part 2 of the Port a simple Direct3D 9 app to DirectX 11 and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) walkthrough.

segment.source: Convert effects to HLSL shaders
segment.target: Convert effects to HLSL shaders

segment.source: The following example is a simple D3DX technique, written for the legacy Effects API, for hardware vertex transformation and pass-through color data.
segment.target: The following example is a simple D3DX technique, written for the legacy Effects API, for hardware vertex transformation and pass-through color data.

segment.source: Direct3D 9 shader code
segment.target: Direct3D 9 shader code

segment.source: In Direct3D 11, we can still use our HLSL shaders.
segment.target: In Direct3D 11, we can still use our HLSL shaders.

segment.source: We put each shader in its own HLSL file so that Visual Studio compiles them into separate files and later, we'll load them as separate Direct3D resources.
segment.target: We put each shader in its own HLSL file so that Visual Studio compiles them into separate files and later, we'll load them as separate Direct3D resources.

segment.source: We set the target level to Shader Model 4 Level 9\_1 (/4\_0\_level\_9\_1) because these shaders are written for DirectX 9.1 GPUs.
segment.target: We set the target level to Shader Model 4 Level 9\_1 (/4\_0\_level\_9\_1) because these shaders are written for DirectX 9.1 GPUs.

segment.source: When we defined the input layout, we made sure it represented the same data structure we use to store per-vertex data in system memory and in GPU memory.
segment.target: When we defined the input layout, we made sure it represented the same data structure we use to store per-vertex data in system memory and in GPU memory.

segment.source: Similarly, the output of a vertex shader should match the structure used as input to the pixel shader.
segment.target: Similarly, the output of a vertex shader should match the structure used as input to the pixel shader.

segment.source: The rules are not the same as passing data from one function to another in C++; you can omit unused variables at the end of the structure.
segment.target: The rules are not the same as passing data from one function to another in C++; you can omit unused variables at the end of the structure.

segment.source: But the order can't be rearranged and you can't skip content in the middle of the data structure.
segment.target: But the order can't be rearranged and you can't skip content in the middle of the data structure.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The rules in Direct3D 9 for binding vertex shaders to pixel shaders were more relaxed than the rules in Direct3D 11.
segment.target: The rules in Direct3D 9 for binding vertex shaders to pixel shaders were more relaxed than the rules in Direct3D 11.

segment.source: The Direct3D 9 arrangement was flexible, but inefficient.
segment.target: The Direct3D 9 arrangement was flexible, but inefficient.

segment.source: It's possible that your HLSL files uses older syntax for shader semantics - for example, COLOR instead of SV\_TARGET.
segment.target: It's possible that your HLSL files uses older syntax for shader semantics - for example, COLOR instead of SV\_TARGET.

segment.source: If so you'll need to enable HLSL compatibility mode (/Gec compiler option) or update the shader semantics to the current syntax.
segment.target: If so you'll need to enable HLSL compatibility mode (/Gec compiler option) or update the shader semantics to the current syntax.

segment.source: The vertex shader in this example has been updated with current syntax.
segment.target: The vertex shader in this example has been updated with current syntax.

segment.source: Here's our hardware transformation vertex shader, this time defined in its own file.
segment.target: Here's our hardware transformation vertex shader, this time defined in its own file.

segment.source: Note Vertex shaders are required to output the SV\_POSITION system value semantic.
segment.target: Note Vertex shaders are required to output the SV\_POSITION system value semantic.

segment.source: This semantic resolves the vertex position data to coordinate values where x is between -1 and 1, y is between -1 and 1, z is divided by the original homogeneous coordinate w value (z/w), and w is 1 divided by the original w value (1/w).
segment.target: This semantic resolves the vertex position data to coordinate values where x is between -1 and 1, y is between -1 and 1, z is divided by the original homogeneous coordinate w value (z/w), and w is 1 divided by the original w value (1/w).

segment.source: HLSL vertex shader (feature level 9.1)
segment.target: HLSL vertex shader (feature level 9.1)

segment.source: This is all we need for our pass-through pixel shader.
segment.target: This is all we need for our pass-through pixel shader.

segment.source: Even though we call it a pass-through, it's actually getting perspective-correct interpolated color data for each pixel.
segment.target: Even though we call it a pass-through, it's actually getting perspective-correct interpolated color data for each pixel.

segment.source: Note that the SV\_TARGET system value semantic is applied to the color value output by our pixel shader as required by the API.
segment.target: Note that the SV\_TARGET system value semantic is applied to the color value output by our pixel shader as required by the API.

segment.source: Note Shader level 9\_x pixel shaders cannot read from the SV\_POSITION system value semantic.
segment.target: Note Shader level 9\_x pixel shaders cannot read from the SV\_POSITION system value semantic.

segment.source: Model 4.0 (and higher) pixel shaders can use SV\_POSITION to retrieve the pixel location on the screen, where x is between 0 and the render target width and y is between 0 and the render target height (each offset by 0.5).
segment.target: Model 4.0 (and higher) pixel shaders can use SV\_POSITION to retrieve the pixel location on the screen, where x is between 0 and the render target width and y is between 0 and the render target height (each offset by 0.5).

segment.source: Most pixel shaders are much more complex than a pass through; note that higher Direct3D feature levels allow a much greater number of calculations per shader program.
segment.target: Most pixel shaders are much more complex than a pass through; note that higher Direct3D feature levels allow a much greater number of calculations per shader program.

segment.source: HLSL pixel shader (feature level 9.1)
segment.target: HLSL pixel shader (feature level 9.1)

segment.source: Compile and load shaders
segment.target: Compile and load shaders

segment.source: Direct3D 9 games often used the Effects library as a convenient way to implement programmable pipelines.
segment.target: Direct3D 9 games often used the Effects library as a convenient way to implement programmable pipelines.

segment.source: Effects could be compiled at run-time using the D3DXCreateEffectFromFile function method.
segment.target: Effects could be compiled at run-time using the D3DXCreateEffectFromFile function method.

segment.source: Loading an effect in Direct3D 9
segment.target: Loading an effect in Direct3D 9

segment.source: Direct3D 11 works with shader programs as binary resources.
segment.target: Direct3D 11 works with shader programs as binary resources.

segment.source: Shaders are compiled when the project is built and then treated as resources.
segment.target: Shaders are compiled when the project is built and then treated as resources.

segment.source: So our example will load the shader bytecode into system memory, use the Direct3D device interface to create a Direct3D resource for each shader, and point to the Direct3D shader resources when we set up each frame.
segment.target: So our example will load the shader bytecode into system memory, use the Direct3D device interface to create a Direct3D resource for each shader, and point to the Direct3D shader resources when we set up each frame.

segment.source: Loading a shader resource in Direct3D 11
segment.target: Loading a shader resource in Direct3D 11

segment.source: To include the shader bytecode in your compiled app package, just add the HLSL file to the Visual Studio project.
segment.target: To include the shader bytecode in your compiled app package, just add the HLSL file to the Visual Studio project.

segment.source: Visual Studio will use the Effect-Compiler Tool (FXC) to compile HLSL files into compiled shader objects (.CSO files) and include them in the app package.
segment.target: Visual Studio will use the Effect-Compiler Tool (FXC) to compile HLSL files into compiled shader objects (.CSO files) and include them in the app package.

segment.source: Note Be sure to set the correct target feature level for the HLSL compiler: right-click the HLSL source file in Visual Studio, select Properties, and change the Shader Model setting under HLSL Compiler - General.
segment.target: Note Be sure to set the correct target feature level for the HLSL compiler: right-click the HLSL source file in Visual Studio, select Properties, and change the Shader Model setting under HLSL Compiler - General.

segment.source: Direct3D checks this property against the hardware capabilities when your app creates the Direct3D shader resource.
segment.target: Direct3D checks this property against the hardware capabilities when your app creates the Direct3D shader resource.

segment.source: hlsl shader properties
segment.target: hlsl shader properties

segment.source: hlsl shader type
segment.target: hlsl shader type

segment.source: This is a good place to create the input layout, which corresponds to the vertex stream declaration in Direct3D 9.
segment.target: This is a good place to create the input layout, which corresponds to the vertex stream declaration in Direct3D 9.

segment.source: The per-vertex data structure needs to match what the vertex shader uses; in Direct3D 11 we have more control over the input layout; we can define the array size and bit length of floating-point vectors and specify semantics for the vertex shader.
segment.target: The per-vertex data structure needs to match what the vertex shader uses; in Direct3D 11 we have more control over the input layout; we can define the array size and bit length of floating-point vectors and specify semantics for the vertex shader.

segment.source: We create a D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structure and use it to inform Direct3D what the per-vertex data will look like.
segment.target: We create a D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structure and use it to inform Direct3D what the per-vertex data will look like.

segment.source: We waited until after we loaded the vertex shader to define the input layout because the API validates the input layout against the vertex shader resource.
segment.target: We waited until after we loaded the vertex shader to define the input layout because the API validates the input layout against the vertex shader resource.

segment.source: If the input layout isn't compatible then Direct3D throws an exception.
segment.target: If the input layout isn't compatible then Direct3D throws an exception.

segment.source: Per-vertex data has to be stored in compatible types in system memory.
segment.target: Per-vertex data has to be stored in compatible types in system memory.

segment.source: DirectXMath data types can help; for example, DXGI\_FORMAT\_R32G32B32\_FLOAT corresponds to XMFLOAT3.
segment.target: DirectXMath data types can help; for example, DXGI\_FORMAT\_R32G32B32\_FLOAT corresponds to XMFLOAT3.

segment.source: Note Constant buffers use a fixed input layout that aligns to four floating-point numbers at a time.
segment.target: Note Constant buffers use a fixed input layout that aligns to four floating-point numbers at a time.

segment.source: XMFLOAT4 (and its derivatives) are recommended for constant buffer data.
segment.target: XMFLOAT4 (and its derivatives) are recommended for constant buffer data.

segment.source: Setting the input layout in Direct3D 11
segment.target: Setting the input layout in Direct3D 11

segment.source: Create geometry resources
segment.target: Create geometry resources

segment.source: In Direct3D 9 we stored geometry resources by creating buffers on the Direct3D device, locking the memory, and copying data from CPU memory to GPU memory.
segment.target: In Direct3D 9 we stored geometry resources by creating buffers on the Direct3D device, locking the memory, and copying data from CPU memory to GPU memory.

segment.source: Direct3D 9
segment.target: Direct3D 9

segment.source: DirectX 11 follows a simpler process.
segment.target: DirectX 11 follows a simpler process.

segment.source: The API automatically copies the data from system memory to the GPU.
segment.target: The API automatically copies the data from system memory to the GPU.

segment.source: We can use COM smart pointers to help make programming easier.
segment.target: We can use COM smart pointers to help make programming easier.

segment.source: DirectX 11
segment.target: DirectX 11

segment.source: Implement the rendering chain
segment.target: Implement the rendering chain

segment.source: Direct3D 9 games often used an effect-based rendering chain.
segment.target: Direct3D 9 games often used an effect-based rendering chain.

segment.source: This type of rendering chain sets up the effect object, provides it with the resources it needs, and lets it render each pass.
segment.target: This type of rendering chain sets up the effect object, provides it with the resources it needs, and lets it render each pass.

segment.source: Direct3D 9 rendering chain
segment.target: Direct3D 9 rendering chain

segment.source: The DirectX 11 rendering chain will still do the same tasks, but the rendering passes need to be implemented differently.
segment.target: The DirectX 11 rendering chain will still do the same tasks, but the rendering passes need to be implemented differently.

segment.source: Instead of putting the specifics in FX files and letting the rendering techniques be more-or-less opaque to our C++ code, we'll set up all our rendering in C++.
segment.target: Instead of putting the specifics in FX files and letting the rendering techniques be more-or-less opaque to our C++ code, we'll set up all our rendering in C++.

segment.source: Here's how our rendering chain will look.
segment.target: Here's how our rendering chain will look.

segment.source: We need to supply the input layout we created after loading the vertex shader, supply each of the shader objects, and specify the constant buffers for each shader to use.
segment.target: We need to supply the input layout we created after loading the vertex shader, supply each of the shader objects, and specify the constant buffers for each shader to use.

segment.source: This example doesn't include multiple rendering passes, but if it did we'd do a similar rendering chain for each pass, changing the setup as needed.
segment.target: This example doesn't include multiple rendering passes, but if it did we'd do a similar rendering chain for each pass, changing the setup as needed.

segment.source: Direct3D 11 rendering chain
segment.target: Direct3D 11 rendering chain

segment.source: The swap chain is part of graphics infrastructure, so we use our DXGI swap chain to present the completed frame.
segment.target: The swap chain is part of graphics infrastructure, so we use our DXGI swap chain to present the completed frame.

segment.source: DXGI blocks the call until the next vsync; then it returns, and our game loop can continue to the next iteration.
segment.target: DXGI blocks the call until the next vsync; then it returns, and our game loop can continue to the next iteration.

segment.source: Presenting a frame to the screen using DirectX 11
segment.target: Presenting a frame to the screen using DirectX 11

segment.source: The rendering chain we just created will be called from a game loop implemented in the IFrameworkView::Run method.
segment.target: The rendering chain we just created will be called from a game loop implemented in the IFrameworkView::Run method.

segment.source: This is shown in Part 3: Viewport and game loop.
segment.target: This is shown in Part 3: Viewport and game loop.
